content.description:
Bruno mentioned one good short climb right in the town of Blairmore.  This was almost certainly it. The name was from a note left at the base of the climb in the late 90’s, likely from one of any number of generational “first (re)ascents”.

Because this is one of the few true jam crack climbs around, it really shouldn’t be missed. The jamming is straight forward, although the start may swallow a bit more of your upper body than you may appreciate. At the top the best spot to belay is from the chains down and to the left of the big block. A long runner makes good protection for the traverse your second will have to complete. A scramble descent off to the left is possible. Nearby bolts make the crack feel a bit more “French” than is perhaps decent for a historic route and a rare area jam crack.  Bring gear to 3”.



The obvious crack. 

Trad. Bring gear to #3.

The short approach, long season, and relatively large number of climbs make this a nice after-work crag.  Except for one fist crack, all climbs are protected by an abundance of bolts. This crag used to see much more traffic, but since the development further up the cliff at the Goat Herder's Saloon (GHS) and over at Emerald Lake, this small crag is often forgotten. 
  
 There are many bolted routes. For now just the main trad line is listed (Patio Lantern). Discover other sport climbs on either side of Patio Lantern, all of which are easy and moderates (5.6 - 5.11).
